title.narrative: Urban Waterbuffer in Valladolid, Spain: Showcasing an innovative solution for circular stormwater management, preventing pluvial flooding and mitigating the effects of drought

description.narrative: • Short general project overviewOver the past 20 years, Spain has lost 20% of its freshwater supply. The ongoing drought has emphatically increased the need to invest in water infrastructure. According to the latest data from the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Environment, water resources are at their lowest level since the 1990s (37% in November 2017). The water reservoirs have lost much of their capacity, with some basins having up to 17% of their capacity in 2017.In addition to increasingly prolonged periods of drought and water shortages, Spain is also increasingly experiencing heavy rainfall, leading to flooding and socio-economic damage. In short: all developments that are leading to ever greater challenges with regard to water security and water safety in Spain.The Dutch start-up Field Factors has developed the Bluebloqs system: an innovative solution to integrate circular water management in urban areas. By collecting, purifying, storing and reusing rainwater underground, the 'Urban Water Buffer' is created at building-to-district level for both water security (e.g. water shortage solution) and water safety (e.g. flood reduction) in urban areas The Bluebloqs system can be fitted into existing infrastructure, area development or restructuring assignments with a minimum above-ground space seizure. In addition to the sustainable availability of water through the collection, purification and storage of rainwater, flooding is avoided at the same time. This allows the buyer of water to guarantee the continuity of its business, which results in a higher operating result and lower operating costs. This innovation has now been tested and implemented in the Urban Water buffer project at the Sparta stadium in Rotterdam, and has also gained notoriety in other countries. Due to existing contacts in Spain (through the Horizon 2020 research project NAIAD) and the specific challenge of the municipality of Valladolid with regard to water shortages and flooding, there is a great opportunity to introduce this Dutch innovation to the Spanish market. The municipality of Valladolid and the water company Aquavall are very enthusiastic about Bluebloqs and see opportunities to apply the system at the Football Stadium Jose Zorrilla in Valladolid.• Initial activities and results of the projectIn order to arrive at a pilot, more information is needed on the technical and economic feasibility in the Spanish situation. This feasibility study is used to get the technical possibilities sharp and to gain insight into the current costs/benefits in order to arrive at a sustainable and cost-effective solution for the municipality, the water company and the operator of the football stadium. If this study shows that the solution is technically implementable and cost-effective, and the partnerships are constructive, then a pilot is the logical follow-up to this feasibility study.
